qas.question: What can be learned from the study of modern hunter-gatherers?
Who thinks that it is useless to study modern foragers since the real ones are gone?
What type of hunter-gatherer has disappeared ?
The "pure hunter-gatherer" appeared not long after what?
Many meaningful things can be learned about prehistoric hunter-gatherers from what?
Nothing meaningful can be learned about modern hunter gatherers from the studies of what?
What do some theorists imply about modern hunter-gatherers?

context: Some of the <a1_0><b6_0>theorists<b6_0/><a1_0/> who advocate this "revisionist" critique imply that, because the "<a2_0>pure hunter-gatherer<a2_0/>" disappeared not long after <b3_0>colonial (or even agricultural) contact began<b3_0/>, <a0_0><b7_0>nothing meaningful<a0_0/> can be learned<b7_0/> about prehistoric hunter-gatherers from <b4_0>studies of <b5_0>modern ones<b5_0/><b4_0/> (Kelly, 24-29; see Wilmsen)
